message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Voice in Human–Agent Interaction
Paper Abstract: Social robots, conversational agents, voice assistants, and other embodied AI are increasingly a feature of everyday life. What connects these various types of intelligent agents is their ability to interact with people through voice. Voice is becoming an essential modality of embodiment, communication, and interaction between computer-based agents and end-users. This survey presents a meta-synthesis on agent voice in the design and experience of agents from a human-centered perspective: voice-based human–agent interaction (vHAI). Findings emphasize the social role of voice in HAI as well as circumscribe a relationship between agent voice and body, corresponding to human models of social psychology and cognition. Additionally, changes in perceptions of and reactions to agent voice over time reveals a generational shift coinciding with the commercial proliferation of mobile voice assistants. The main contributions of this work are a vHAI classification framework for voice across various agent forms, contexts, and user groups, a critical analysis grounded in key theories, and an identification of future directions for the oncoming wave of vocal machines.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Embodied agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embodied_agent"},{"title":"Dialogue system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialog_system"},{"title":"Conversational user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversational_user_interface"},{"title":"Amelia (company) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amelia_(company)"},{"title":"Chatbot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot"},{"title":"Pedagogical agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedagogical_agent"},{"title":"Agency (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agency_(sociology)"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of conversational agents:

## Definition

A dialogue system, or conversational agent (CA), is a computer system intended to converse with a human.(no content)Dialogue systems employed one or more of text, speech, graphics, haptics, gestures, and other modes for communication on both the input and output channel.

## Types of Conversational Agents

There are two main categories of conversational interfaces; voice assistants and chatbots. 

- **Voice Assistants**: A voice user interface allows a user to complete an action by speaking a command.
- **Chatbots**: A chatbot is a web- or mobile-based interface that allows the user to ask questions and retrieve information.

## Technology

Conversational interfaces use natural language processing (NLP) to allow computers to understand, analyze, and create meaning from human language.(no content)Modern chatbots are typically online and use generative artificial intelligence systems that are capable of maintaining a conversation with a user in natural language and simulating the way a human would behave as a conversational partner.

## Applications

A major area where chatbots have long been used is customer service and support, with various sorts of virtual assistants. Additional applications include virtual training environments, portable personal navigation guides, interactive fiction and storytelling systems, interactive online characters and automated presenters and commentators.

## Applications

A major area where chatbots have long been used is customer service and support, with various sorts of virtual assistants. message_text:
Web search results for query: "embodied AI"

Links: [{"title":"Embodied agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embodied_agent"},{"title":"Artificial consciousness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_consciousness"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Cynthia Breazeal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JIBO"},{"title":"Katherine Elkins - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katherine_Elkins"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of embodied AI:

## Definition

In artificial intelligence, an embodied agent is an intelligent agent that interacts with the environment through a physical body within that environment. However, agents that are represented graphically with a body, for example a human or a cartoon animal, are also called embodied agents, although they have only virtual, not physical, embodiment.

## Types and Applications

There are different categories of embodied AI:

- **Physically embodied agents**: Mobile robots are one example of physically embodied agents
- **Graphically embodied agents**: Embodied conversational agents are embodied agents (usually with a graphical front-end as opposed to a robotic body) that are capable of engaging in conversation with one another and with humans employing the same verbal and nonverbal means that humans do (such as gesture, facial expression, and so forth).(no content)Embodied conversational agents have also been used in virtual training environments, portable personal navigation guides, interactive fiction and storytelling systems, interactive online characters and automated presenters and commentators.

## Research Context

A fundamental criticism of the simulated brain approach derives from embodied cognition theory, which asserts that human embodiment is an essential aspect of human intelligence and is necessary to ground meaning. If this theory is correct, any fully functional brain model will need to encompass more than just the neurons (e.g., a robotic body).

message_text:
Web search results for query: "social robots"

Links: [{"title":"Social robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_robot"},{"title":"Sociorobotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociorobotics"},{"title":"Nadine Social Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadine_Social_Robot"},{"title":"Category:Social robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Social_robots"},{"title":"Media Lab Europe's social robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_Lab_Europe's_social_robots"},{"title":"Socially assistive robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socially_assistive_robot"},{"title":"Leonardo (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonardo_(robot)"},{"title":"Japanese robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_robotics"},{"title":"Hedonic game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hedonic_game"},{"title":"Tico Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tico_Robot"}]

Here are the search results for **social robots**:

## Definition and Overview

Social robots interact socially with humans or evoke social responses from them.(no content)The nature of the social interactions is immaterial and may range from relatively simple supportive tasks, such as passing tools to a worker, to complex expressive communication and collaboration, such as assistive healthcare.

## Development History

Since the 1990s, artificial intelligence and robotics researchers have developed robots which explicitly engage on a social level.(no content)The evolution of social robots began with autonomous robots designed to have little to no interaction with humans—essentially designed to take on what humans could not, handling hazardous conditions and assignments that could potentially put humans in danger.

## Applications

Social robots are starting to follow humans into much more personal settings like home, health care, and education. A specialized subset called socially assistive robots (SARs) have additional applications: SARs have been developed and validated in a wide array of applications, including healthcare, elder care, education, and training.

## Human Interaction and Challenges

Many people are uneasy about interacting socially with a robot and, in general, people tend to prefer smaller robots to large humanoid robots. However, exposure to a social robot may decrease uncertainty and increase willingness to interact with the robot, and research shows that over time people speak for a longer time and share more information in their disclosures to a social robot.

## Notable Examples

Some well-known social robots include Nadine, a humanoid robot developed at Nanyang Technological University, and Leonardo, which was designed with expressive capabilities to encourage natural human-robot interaction.

Links: [{"title":"Voice assistants - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Voice_assistants&redirect=no"},{"title":"Virtual assistant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_assistant_(artificial_intelligence)"},{"title":"Google Assistant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Assistant"},{"title":"Gender digital divide - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Female_gendering_of_AI_technologies"},{"title":"Roberto Pieraccini - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Pieraccini"},{"title":"Kruti - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft:Kruti"},{"title":"Celia (virtual assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celia_(virtual_assistant)"},{"title":"The Georgetown Voice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Georgetown_Voice"},{"title":"Lyra (virtual assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyra_(virtual_assistant)"},{"title":"Bixby (software) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bixby_(software)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about voice assistants:

## What are Voice Assistants?

A virtual assistant is a software agent that can perform a range of tasks or services for a user based on user input such as commands or questions, including verbal ones.(no content)Virtual assistants use natural language processing (NLP) to match user text or voice input to executable commands.

## Importance and Usage

Voice assistants have become central to technology platforms and, in many countries, to day-to-day life.(no content)Voice assistants now manage upwards of 1 billion tasks per month, from the mundane (changing a song) to the essential (contacting emergency services).

## Major Voice Assistants

Popular voice assistants include Amazon Alexa on Amazon Echo devices, Siri on an iPhone, Google Assistant on Google-enabled Android devices, and Bixby on Samsung devices.(no content)Google Assistant is available in more than 90 countries and over 30 languages, and is used by more than 500 million users monthly.(no content)Bixby is a virtual assistant developed by Samsung Electronics that runs on various Samsung-branded appliances, primarily mobile devices but also some refrigerators televisions and PCs.

## Capabilities

Assistant is able to answer questions, schedule events and alarms, adjust hardware settings on the user's device, show information from the user's Google account, play games, and more.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about voice assistants:

## What are Voice Assistants?

A virtual assistant is a software agent that can perform a range of tasks or services for a user based on user input such as commands or questions, including verbal ones.(no content)Virtual assistants use natural language processing (NLP) to match user text or voice input to executable commands.

## Importance and Usage

Voice assistants have become central to technology platforms and, in many countries, to day-to-day life.(no content)Voice assistants now manage upwards of 1 billion tasks per month, from the mundane (changing a song) to the essential (contacting emergency services).

## Major Voice Assistants

Popular voice assistants include Amazon Alexa on Amazon Echo devices, Siri on an iPhone, Google Assistant on Google-enabled Android devices, and Bixby on Samsung devices.(no content)Google Assistant is available in more than 90 countries and over 30 languages, and is used by more than 500 million users monthly.(no content)Bixby is a virtual assistant developed by Samsung Electronics that runs on various Samsung-branded appliances, primarily mobile devices but also some refrigerators televisions and PCs.

## Capabilities

Assistant is able to answer questions, schedule events and alarms, adjust hardware settings on the user's device, show information from the user's Google account, play games, and more.

Web search results for query: "social psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Social psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_psychology"},{"title":"List of social psychology theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_social_psychology_theories"},{"title":"Social Psychology Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Psychology_Network"},{"title":"Society of Experimental Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_of_Experimental_Social_Psychology"},{"title":"Journal of Personality and Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Personality_and_Social_Psychology"},{"title":"Social media and psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_and_psychology"},{"title":"Personality and Social Psychology Review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_and_Social_Psychology_Review"},{"title":"Society for Personality and Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_Personality_and_Social_Psychology"},{"title":"Social Psychology (Community) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Psychology_(Community)"},{"title":"European Journal of Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Journal_of_Social_Psychology"}]

Here are the search results for "social psychology":

## Definition and Overview

Social psychology is the methodical study of how thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are influenced by the actual, imagined, or implied presence of others.(no content)Social psychologists typically explain human behavior as a result of the relationship between mental states and social situations, studying the social conditions under which thoughts, feelings, and behaviors occur, and how these variables influence social interactions.

## Historical Development

In the 19th century, social psychology began to emerge from the larger field of psychology, with one of the first published studies in the field being Norman Triplett's 1898 experiment on the phenomenon of social facilitation.(no content)According to Wolfgang Stroebe, modern social psychology began in 1924 with the publication of a classic textbook by Floyd Allport, which defined the field as the experimental study of social behavior.

## Key Research Areas

Social psychology utilizes a wide range of specific theories for various kinds of social and cognitive phenomena. Major theories include attribution theory, cognitive dissonance, and self-determination theory. Most modern researchers in the 21st century are interested in phenomena such as attribution, social cognition, and self-concept.

## Applications

Social psychologists are concerned with applied psychology, contributing towards applications of social psychology in health, education, law, and the workplace.

Web search results for query: "voice user interface"

Links: [{"title":"Voice user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voice_user_interface"},{"title":"Conversational user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversational_user_interfaces"},{"title":"Thomson SmartVision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SmartVision"},{"title":"Zero-G Ltd - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-G_Ltd"},{"title":"Microsoft Speech API - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_Application_Programming_Interface"},{"title":"Radio Network Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_Network_Controller"},{"title":"Adobe XD - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adobe_Experience_Design"}]

Here are the search results for "voice user interface":

## Overview

A voice user interface (VUI) enables spoken human interaction with computers, using speech recognition to understand spoken commands and answer questions, and typically text to speech to play a reply.

## How They Work

Advances in technologies like text-to-speech, speech-to-text, natural language processing, and cloud services contributed to the mass adoption of these types of interfaces.(no content)Newer voice command devices are speaker-independent, so they can respond to multiple voices, regardless of accent or dialectal influences.

## Applications and Devices

Apple's Siri, introduced in October 2011, was one of the first voice assistants widely adopted, allowing users of iPhone to get information and complete actions on their device simply by asking Siri.(no content)Further development has continued to include home based devices such as Google Home or Amazon Echo (powered by Alexa) that allow users to "connect" their homes through a series of smart devices.

## Challenges

Voice interfaces pose a substantial number of challenges for usability. Unlike graphical user interfaces (GUIs), best practices for voice interface design are still emergent. With purely audio-based interaction, voice user interfaces tend to suffer from low discoverability—it is difficult for users to understand the scope of a system's capabilities.

Web search results for query: "cognition"

Links: [{"title":"Cognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognition"},{"title":"Cognition AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognition_AI"},{"title":"Cognitive psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_psychology"},{"title":"Cognitive science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_science"},{"title":"Category:Cognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Cognition"},{"title":"Cognitive skill - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_skill"},{"title":"Cognitive impairment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_impairment"},{"title":"Evolution of cognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_of_cognition"},{"title":"Cognition (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognition_(journal)"},{"title":"Need for cognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Need_for_cognition"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of cognition:

## Definition

Cognitions are mental activities that deal with knowledge and encompass psychological processes that acquire, store, retrieve, transform, or otherwise use information.(no content)Cognitions are a pervasive part of mental life, helping individuals understand and interact with the world.

## Key Cognitive Processes

Cognition is not limited to abstract reasoning and encompasses diverse psychological processes, including perception, attention, memory, language, and decision-making.(no content)Many cognitive activities deal with language, including language acquisition, comprehension, and production.

## Conscious and Unconscious Cognition

Cognitive activities can happen consciously, like when a person deliberately analyzes a problem step by step, or unconsciously, such as automatic mechanisms responsible for language processing and facial recognition.

## Scientific Study

Cognitive psychology is the scientific study of human mental processes such as attention, language use, memory, perception, problem solving, creativity, and reasoning. Additionally, cognitive science is the interdisciplinary, scientific study of the mind and its processes and examines the nature, the tasks, and the functions of cognition.

## Theories of Cognition

Classical computationalism argues that cognitive processes manipulate symbols according to mechanical rules, similar to how computers execute algorithms, while connectionism models the mind as a complex network of nodes where information flows as nodes communicate with each other.

Links: [{"title":"Human-agent team - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-agent_team"},{"title":"Human-AI interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-AI_interaction"},{"title":"Human–computer interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–computer_interaction"},{"title":"Human–robot interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_interaction"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Human–robot collaboration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_collaboration"},{"title":"Human-centered computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-centered_computing"},{"title":"Agent detection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperactive_agency_detection_device"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of human-agent interaction:

## Definition and Scope

A human-agent team is a system composed of multiple interacting humans and artificial intelligence systems, where the artificial intelligence system may be a robotic system, a decision support system, or a virtual agent.(no content)Human agent teaming provides an interaction paradigm that differs from traditional approaches such as supervisory control or user interface design, by enabling the computer to have a certain degree of autonomy.

## Key Characteristics

Human-AI interaction has been theorized in the context of interpersonal relationships mainly in social psychology, communications and media studies, and as a technology interface through the lens of human-computer interaction and computer-mediated communication.(no content)Some findings show signs of human-AI augmentation, in which AI enhances human ability so that co-working on a task with AI produces better outcomes than a human working alone, such as increased quality and speed of customer service tasks.

## Collaboration Models

Human-AI collaboration occurs when the human and AI supervise the task on the same level and extent to achieve the same goal.(no content)Human-Robot Collaboration is the study of collaborative processes in which human and robot agents work together to achieve shared goals, and many new applications for robots require them to work alongside people as capable members of human-robot teams.

## Applications

Human agent teaming is a popular paradigm to approach the interaction between humans and AI technologies in various domains such as defense, healthcare, space, and disaster response.

Human-agent interaction represents an evolving field that combines elements of robotics, AI, human factors, and social dynamics to create effective collaborative systems.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
## Analysis Complete

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Voice in Human–Agent Interaction" and created a comprehensive knowledge graph representation. Here's a summary of the findings:

### Paper Classification
**Type:** Survey - This is a meta-synthesis literature review that examines existing work on agent voice in human-agent interaction from a human-centered perspective.

### Identified Entities
The analysis extracted 8 key entities from the paper's title and abstract:

1. **Social robot** (artifact) - Core subject examining how social robots interact with humans through voice
2. **Dialogue system** (tool) - Conversational agents forming a key agent category
3. **Virtual assistant** (artifact) - Voice assistants and mobile voice assistants discussed in the survey
4. **Embodied agent** (concept) - Foundational for understanding voice as an embodiment modality
5. **Human-AI interaction** (concept) - Broader research context for voice-based interaction
6. **Voice user interface** (tool) - Technological foundation for voice-based communication
7. **Social psychology** (concept) - Theoretical framework for analyzing social roles of voice
8. **Cognition** (concept) - Cognitive models for understanding human perception and reactions

All 8 triples have been validated against Wikipedia URLs and the validation script confirms:
- ✅ Valid paper type classification
- ✅ All entities properly categorized
- ✅ All Wikipedia URLs verified and correct
- ✅ Proper relationships specified (all "uses" relations appropriate for a survey)

Sources:
- [Social robot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_robot)
- [Dialog system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialog_system)
- [Virtual assistant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_assistant_(artificial_intelligence))
- [Embodied agent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embodied_agent)
- [Human-AI interaction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-AI_interaction)
- [Voice user interface](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voice_user_interface)
- [Social psychology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_psychology)
- [Cognition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognition)
